channel.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
channel.description:
http://infowars.net/articles/april2007/040407cameras.htm
In an incredibly Orwellian move, loudspeakers are to be fitted to surveillance cameras throughout major cities, allowing CCTV operators to bark commands at people who drop litter, act in an aggressive manner or loiter.

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @PaulT PaulT
item.description:
@PaulT wrote:

Moore's law applies to a very specific situation by the way, you can't just randomly decide that it fits any scenario you care to dream up. (It has nothing to do with facial recognition software.) :p

Current face recognition software is only effective slightly over 50% of the time. In my opinion Moore’s law will eventually wrinkle out almost all difficulties in making computers sentient, simply by providing hardware so powerful that software doesn’t need to improve a great deal to become vastly more effective. And eventually you will have computers that cross-reference face shape and texture with time/space location and figure out not only who you are but where you came from, where you’re going, when you left, and when you will arrive.

Read full topic
item.source: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:52, topic:74507”][quote author=PaulT link=topic=109418.msg1092921#msg1092921 date=1175744344]
Facial recognition software exists and though it’s not perfect we all know Moore’s Law will sort that out soon enough. I’m not saying this will happen right away, but this is the first step down the slippery slope toward Dystopia.
[/quote]

Citing Moore’s law is the new black!

Moore’s law applies to a very specific situation by the way, you can’t just randomly decide that it fits any scenario you care to dream up. (It has nothing to do with facial recognition software.) :p[/quote]
Now that you mention it, isn’t Moore’s law just the concept that the power of CPUs will double every 18 - 24 months?

Read full topic

Citing Moore’s law is the new black!

Moore’s law applies to a very specific situation by the way, you can’t just randomly decide that it fits any scenario you care to dream up. (It has nothing to do with facial recognition software.)

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

chewwie:

im australian and john howard is gay dont like him the big eye brow fella but since im 15 i dunno what the polls going is he winning the elevtives (cant spell it) is he winning hope not…?

Believe it or not, I think Johnny Howard has done, and will continue to do, a better job then whoever the new ALP politician is. That discussion belongs elsewhere though. :rolleyes:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:48, topic:74507”][quote author=lothy link=topic=109418.msg1100656#msg1100656 date=1175865364]
Well, I’m nearly 18. I wouldn’t mind a gun. But that article won’t change the fact that they’re illegal.
[/quote]

But they need to be made legal. Do you have the right to hold demonstrations, publish articles and basically get your cause heard?[/quote]
It really depends. In some states of Australia you have to actually go through government channels to hold demonstrations and anything that would be in a public place. Of course, I’ve never heard of them refusing things either - I think it’s just so that things can be setup (eg detours, and perhaps police to ensure there aren’t riots).
Having said that, I’m not the type of person that gets up in front of a crowd.
EDIT: As for articles, I’m really not sure. I doubt they’d be published in anything worthwhile though.

Read full topic

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

juju:

[quote]The framers of the Constitution understood that an armed society is a safe society.

What kind of logic is that? No wonder the US has a high gun murder rate per capita, do you really think you’re safe?[/quote]

What you ignored the rest of the quote that explained that statement?

The Second Amendment is an insurance policy to protect freedom for every citizen. The framers of the Constitution understood that an armed society is a safe society. They understood that everyone is safer when criminals do not know who is armed, that foreign nations don't relish the thought of attacking an armed people, and that no government wants to oppress a citizenry that has the power to resist.

Do I think I’m safe? Absolutely, I have a gun sitting right here.

The question is, are you as safe as I am? The answer to that is no:

WND – 2 Mar 01

Britain, Australia top U.S. in violent crime - WND - WND

Law enforcement and anti-crime activists regularly claim that the United States tops the charts in most crime-rate categories, but a new international study says that America’s former master — Great Britain — has much higher levels of crime. The...

Britain, Australia top U.S. in violent crime Rates Down Under increase despite strict gun-control measures

Law enforcement and anti-crime activists regularly claim that the United States tops the charts in most crime-rate categories, but a new international study says that America’s former master – Great Britain – has much higher levels of crime.

The International Crime Victims Survey, conducted by Leiden University in Holland, found that England and Wales ranked second overall in violent crime among industrialized nations.

Twenty-six percent of English citizens – roughly one-quarter of the population – have been victimized by violent crime. Australia led the list with more than 30 percent of its population victimized.

The United States didn’t even make the “top 10” list of industrialized nations whose citizens were victimized by crime.

Jack Straw, the British home secretary, admitted that “levels of victimization are higher than in most comparable countries for most categories of crime.”

Highlights of the study indicated that:

* The percentage of the population that suffered "contact crime" in England and Wales was 3.6 percent, compared with 1.9 percent in the United States and 0.4 percent in Japan.

* Burglary rates in England and Wales were also among the highest recorded. Australia (3.9 percent) and Denmark (3.1 per cent) had higher rates of burglary with entry than England and Wales (2.8 percent). In the U.S., the rate was 2.6 percent, according to 1995 figures;

* "After Australia and England and Wales, the highest prevalence of crime was in Holland (25 percent), Sweden (25 percent) and Canada (24 percent). The United States, despite its high murder rate, was among the middle ranking countries with a 21 percent victimization rate," the London Telegraph said.

* England and Wales also led in automobile thefts. More than 2.5 percent of the population had been victimized by car theft, followed by 2.1 percent in Australia and 1.9 percent in France. Again, the U.S. was not listed among the "top 10" nations.

* The study found that Australia led in burglary rates, with nearly 4 percent of the population having been victimized by a burglary. Denmark was second with 3.1 percent; the U.S. was listed eighth at about 1.8 percent.

Interestingly, the study found that one of the lowest victimization rates – just 15 percent overall – occurred in Northern Ireland, home of the Irish Republican Army and scene of years of terrorist violence.

Analysts in the U.S. were quick to point out that all of the other industrialized nations included in the survey had stringent gun-control laws, but were overall much more violent than the U.S.

Indeed, information on Handgun Control’s Center to Prevent Handgun Violence website actually praises Australia and attempts to portray Australia as a much safer country following strict gun-control measures passed by lawmakers in 1996.

“The next time a credulous friend or acquaintance tells you that Australia actually suffered more crime when they got tougher on guns … offer him a Foster’s, and tell him the facts,” the CPHV site says.

“In 1998, the rate at which firearms were used in murder, attempted murder, assault, sexual assault and armed robbery went down. In that year, the last for which statistics are available, the number of murders involving a firearm declined to its lowest point in four years,” says CPHV.

However, the International Crime Victims Survey notes that overall crime victimization Down Under rose from 27.8 percent of the population in 1988, to 28.6 percent in 1991 to over 30 percent in 1999.

Advocates of less gun control in the U.S. say the drop in gun murder rates was more than offset by the overall victimization increase. Also, they note that Australia leads the ICVS report in three of four categories – burglary (3.9 percent of the population), violent crime (4.1 percent) and overall victimization (about 31 percent).

Australia is second to England in auto theft (2.1 percent).

In March 2000, WorldNetDaily reported that since Australia’s widespread gun ban, violent crime had increased in the country.

WND reported that, although lawmakers responsible for passing the ban promised a safer country, the nation’s crime statistics tell a different story:

* Countrywide, homicides are up 3.2 percent.
* Assaults are up 8.6 percent.
* Amazingly, armed robberies have climbed nearly 45 percent.
* In the Australian state of Victoria, gun homicides have climbed 300 percent.
* In the 25 years before the gun bans, crime in Australia had been dropping steadily.
* There has been a reported "dramatic increase" in home burglaries and assaults on the elderly.</blockquote>

Read full topic

Australia doesn’t have this kind of stuff going on.

Because we don’t have freedom of speech.In Australia we never did.Found this out the s’morning.Some guy was being racist…He said he was expressing his freedom of speech.Also most of Australia has a set thought on something.I’ve noticed this,most of my school mates are like Jellys.They believe anything the T.V and perantals tell them.
[/quote]wtf is a jelly?
I wish I was Australian.America is pretty much the worst country out there.Rather live in Canada.[/quote]
Think if you put a tooth pick in the Jelly

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jelly You Americans might call it Gelatine(Australian spelling,drop the e)?Well put in the dessert and the hole closes up.Well this is sorta the same with my friends.They get told one bit of information and it’s stuck.Even if it’s wrong.Like for instance there hate for Asian people.There migrating over to Australia and there like "Fhking Asians shouldn’t be in OUR country"Yet the don’t understand that there ancestors where British.
Also there religion.I said I’m not a believe in Jesus and one of my friends hit me.I was like “WTF”

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“juju, post:37, topic:74507”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=109418.msg1093524#msg1093524 date=1175750973]
It will never get that far, because of our right to bear arms. <3 USA

Australia has no protection, your government can do whatever they want with you, and you have no recourse.
[/quote]

Ah, yes, and the US has “freedom”?
Due to the Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001(USA PATRIOT Act) that was introduced soon after 9/11 your government can tap you lines, monitor your emails and much more if they ‘feel’ that you are a threat to national security.[/quote]

Yes, we do have freedom, it is you who don’t:

The Second Amendment is an insurance policy to protect freedom for every citizen. The framers of the Constitution understood that an armed society is a safe society. They understood that everyone is safer when criminals do not know who is armed, that foreign nations don't relish the thought of attacking an armed people, and that no government wants to oppress a citizenry that has the power to resist.
Townhall

Equal rights under the Second Amendment

Ken Blackwell: On March 9, a good thing happened for people

Read full topic
item.source: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching

Ah, yes, and the US has “freedom”?
Due to the Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001(USA PATRIOT Act) that was introduced soon after 9/11 your government can tap you lines, monitor your emails and much more if they ‘feel’ that you are a threat to national security.

item.title: Big Brother is Here. And He's Watching
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“lothy, post:30, topic:74507”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=109418.msg1094754#msg1094754 date=1175775782]

It took me some searching, but I found the Port Arthur incident you speak of: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Port_Arthur_Massacre

Then it has to be explained to the people of Australia that their thinking is backwards, bans on guns increase the possibility of incidents like that, if people in Port Arthur had been carrying guns on them very few to none people would have died.

A very similar incident of a crazed man killing multiple people occured in Texas, but instead of banning guns the government did the smart thing, and passed a law to provide for the concealed carry of guns. I am looking for the article now, I read it yesterday…

edit:

here are articles on it:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luby's_massacre
http://www.chron.com/content/chronicle/nation/guns/part2/gunside1.html

I read through the first one, and a bit of the second one - don’t you get a bit worried walking down the street knowing that anyone around you could sneak up behind you and put a gun to your head?

Anyone could sneak up behind you anywhere and put a gun to your head, a concealed carry law gives you the right to have a gun as well, in case something like that happened.
[/quote]
Well, the odds of anyone having a gun where I live for any reason at all are incredibly small. So sure, it’s possibly anywhere - but the odds are a lot lower here.[/quote]

Still you aren’t thinking about it correctly, the chance a criminal will be carrying a gun is the same here or there. Which makes it safer here because law-abiding citizens have the right to carry guns as well.

MybJames:

jelly, is what you americans call jam.

We use the words jelly and jam in America too, maybe he just hasn’t heard of it.

Read full topic
